title: 104_s1620
content: The Act titled "Environmental Dredge Disposal Act of 1996" establishes regulations for dredged material disposal facilities. The Water Resources Development Act of 1986 is amended to include provisions for dredged material disposal facilities associated with Federal navigation projects. The Water Resources Development Act of 1986 now includes provisions for material disposal facilities related to Federal navigation projects, considered a general navigation feature for cost sharing. The Water Resources Development Act of 1986 includes provisions for material disposal facilities related to Federal navigation projects for cost sharing under this section. The Water Resources Development Act of 1986 allows funds from the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund to be used for construction and maintenance of material disposal facilities for Federal navigation projects. The Secretary can determine when funds are no longer needed for eligible costs related to commercial navigation. The maximum federal share for operation and maintenance costs is specified. The Secretary can decide when funds from the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund are no longer needed for eligible operation and maintenance costs for commercial navigation. The maximum federal share for these costs is $25,000,000 per fiscal year. The Federal share of operation and maintenance costs for a project shall not exceed $25,000,000 per fiscal year. Eligible costs include constructing dredged material disposal facilities for Federal navigation projects. The Federal share of operation and maintenance costs for Federal navigation projects includes constructing and operating dredged material disposal facilities for harbors and inland harbors. The Federal government covers costs for operating and maintaining dredged material disposal facilities for harbors, inland harbors, and environmental dredging for contaminated sediments in Federal navigation channels. The Federal government covers costs for environmental dredging and disposal facilities for contaminated sediments in Federal navigation channels and critical port and harbor areas to facilitate maritime commerce and navigation. The Federal government covers costs for dredging, management, and disposal of contaminated sediments in critical port and harbor areas to support maritime commerce and navigation, with preference given to areas where harbor maintenance fees exceed Federal expenditures. The Secretary gives preference to port areas where harbor maintenance fees exceed Federal expenditures for dredged material disposal facilities. Expenditures for eligible port projects can be reimbursed from the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund if contracts for construction have not been awarded before the enactment of this subsection. Expenditures for eligible port projects can be reimbursed from the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund if contracts for construction have not been awarded before the enactment of this subsection. Amendment of existing agreements between the Secretary and a non-Federal interest must be requested within 30 days after the enactment of this subsection. Each cooperative agreement between the Secretary and a non-Federal interest must be amended to conform to this subsection within 30 days of enactment, including provisions on project costs for dredged material disposal facilities. The Federal interest shall be amended to conform to this subsection, including provisions on project costs for dredged material disposal facilities. The amendment to cooperative agreements must be applied prospectively and shall not increase non-Federal costs. The amendment to cooperative agreements must be applied prospectively and shall not increase non-Federal costs for dredged material disposal facilities.
